_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary:

Airgas USA, L.P. an Air Liquide Company (Airgas - Airgas Merchant Gases) operates a stationary anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system in the liquid production of carbon dioxide (CO2) with approximately five (5) employees in Blissfield, Michigan. The Blissfield refrigeration process can store up to approximately 18,000 lbs. (maximum intended inventory) of liquefied ammonia under pressure in the main receiver, all connected piping, compression, condensers and related processes vessels involved in the facility. This covered process exceeds the listed regulatory threshold quantity (TQ) of 10,000 lbs. for anhydrous ammonia and is subject to chemical accident prevention provisions.

Regulated Chemical:

Anhydrous ammonia is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions, presented in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 (40 CFR Part 68) (the RMP Rule Level 3). Anhydrous ammonia is also subject to the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration process safety management program presented in Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119 (OSHA PSM). General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps: The highly toxic nature of ammonia in the process makes it necessary for Airgas to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human and environmental exposure and to reduce the potential threat to personnel and nearby members of the community. Airgas policy is to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local rules and regulations. Airgas has also implemented specific chemical prevention steps to help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors. The following are examples of the types of safety features in place: (1) Release Detection - Ammonia detectors located around covered process equipment to detect and alarm. (2) Release Mitigation - Personal protective equipment;

e.g., personal gas detectors, protective outerwear clothing, safety googles, shoes, etc. (3) System Integrity - Automatic control and manual valves that provide isolation for ammonia process equipment, check valves on ammonia loading lines and pressure safety valves for the process piping and vessels. (4) Facility and Environment - Contracted emergency response specialists.

Employee Participation (EP):

Airgas has developed a written plan of action and Blissfield employee/operators are expected to participate in the accidental release prevention program (RMP/PSM). Employees are trained on and provided access to the ammonia refrigeration process safety information. Specific actions of employee involvement in the accident prevention program are documented in the
Employee Participation plan. Forms of participation include being part of a PHA, a PSSR, and/or being involved in incident investigation. Employees participate in monthly safety meetings where process safety issues are discussed and corrective actions are developed, and they are involved in the review of the covered process operating procedures annually to ensure they are current, accurate and recommend any necessary changes.

Process Safety Information (PSI):

Airgas keeps a variety of technical documents onsite and in the company's electronic document control system that are used to help maintain safe operation of its processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, equipment design/configuration information, specific chemical inventories and operation limits for key process parameters - all key information for operating the process safely. Employees are trained to operate the process using process controls and instrumentation within these safe operating limits. The Facility Manager is responsible for maintaining up-to-date process safety information. A table summarizing the reference documents and their location is kept accurate and is readily accessible as part of th

e written employee participation.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):

Airgas has a risk management program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. The covered process underwent an initial process hazard analysis (PHA) and will continue to undergo periodic review/re-validations at least every five years or as required by Management Of Change (MOC). The PHA team consists of members with the appropriate experience to define the hazards and mitigating controls of the process and also represents a cross-section of the employees working in the process. For future PHA reviews, local and corporate management will review the PHA team findings and develop a resolution action plan for each item, which will be documented, tracked and ultimately closed in the Airgas action item database tracking system. The facility manager is responsible for prioritizing and tracking implementation of the action plan to closure.

Operating Procedures (OP):

Airgas maintains controlled written procedures that address various modes of liquefied and gaseous ammonia process operations, such as: (1) unit initial startup; (2) unit normal operations; (3) unit temporary operations; (4) unit emergency shutdown; (5) unit emergency operations; (6) unit normal shutdown and; (7) unit startup after turnaround or emergency shutdown. Additionally, the emergency shutdown procedure includes conditions that will prompt a shutdown and identifies qualified and responsible operators to complete the steps in a safe and timely manner. Airgas operating procedures have safe operating limits identified along with consequences of unsafe deviation. Procedures further provide steps for operators to take that will correct or avoid an unsafe deviation. Airgas procedures are used by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate by the facility manager.

Training (TN):

Airgas has implemented a training program for all employee/operators involved in the ammonia covered process. All employees receive a combination of classroom, computer-based (CBT) and hands-on training that addresses such topics as: general orientation, facility rules and practices, process safety information, normal and emergency operating procedures, health and safety consideration, use of safety procedures and equipment, incident investigation and emergency response. In addition, all operators are required to attend refresher training at least every three years. Training is documented and tracked on a local training matrix and electronically in the Airgas University training system.

Mechanical Integrity (MI):

Airgas has established mechanical integrity (MI) practices and procedures, based on preventative philosophy, to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief valves and vent systems, controls and interlocks, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests; (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these written activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment. The MI program assists with the verification and suitability of new and existing process equipment and, as well as quality control of spare parts and modifications to existing process equipment.

Management of Change (MOC):

Airgas's Management Of Change (MOC) procedure has established the requirements for ensuring proposed process or equipment changes or changes indirectly affecting processes are evaluated, approved and documented prior to implementation through the use of a written management of change process. The MOC procedure outlines the requirements for documenting, evaluating the impact,

and approving planned deviations from procedure. All MOC's are submitted, reviewed by a subjective matter specialist (such as Engineering, Risk Management, Operations, Health and
Safety), approved, tracked and closed using an electronic approval and tracking system. Upon closure, personnel whose assigned job functions are impacted by the MOC, are briefed and /or trained in the MOC requirements.

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSR):

Airgas ensures the safety of new/modified facilities or processes before placing those facilities or processes into service through the use of pre-startup safety reviews (PSSR's). An Airgas PSSR is intended to ensure safety through confirmation that: (1) construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications; (2) safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and adequate; (3) PHA's have been performed and recommendations resolved before startup of new plants or processes; (4) MOC requirements have been satisfied for modified facilities; and (5) training has been completed and documented for affected operator/employees.

Compliance Audits (CA):

To help ensure the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Airgas conducts an internal compliance audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accidental release prevention program are being implemented adequately. Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years. Resolutions to recommendations are documented, tracked and closed.
Once the resolutions have been completed, changes are communicated to operating, maintenance and other employees whose work assignments are in the covered process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions. Training and communication is documented.

Incident Investigation (II):

Airgas defines management systems and establishes the requirements for communicating, investigating and reporting of incidents at all facilities through the use of an Incident Inve

stigation and reporting procedure. Airgas documents incident and subsequent investigation, follow up actions, and closure in an electronic document control system. The Facility Manager is responsible for maintaining a log and tracking incidents and corrective actions through completion. Results of findings and corrective actions are shared with employee/operators who could be affected by the findings. Reports are retained for at least five years to be reviewed during future PHA's and revalidations.

Safe & Hot Work Permit System (HWP):

Airgas has a safe & hot work permit system in place to help ensure worker and process safety. This system is comprised of a group of corporate procedures, standards and forms under the life safety program. Procedures in place include: (1) energy control; (2) safe work; (3) hot work; (4) confined space entry. Plant personnel are trained on these safe work practices to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed professionally and safely.

Contractors (CON):

Airgas uses contractors to supplement its own work force when maintenance activities exceed the capabilities or time available for their own employee/operators. Contractors are made aware of the potential dangers involved with a system covered by PSM/RMP regulations. Procedures are in place to make sure that contractors: (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, and (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, prior to their beginning work. Periodically contractors are evaluated to ensure that both their safety performance and training required for work on the ammonia refrigeration system meets Airgas safety standards.

Five-Year Accident History (AH):

The Blissfield CO2 production facility has experienced no accident resulting in an uncontrolled ammonia release either on or offsite in the last five (5) years for the covered ammonia pr

ocess.

Emergency Response Program Information (ERP):

The Blissfield CO2 production facility has developed a written emergency action plan. The plan outlines action to be taken at the plant by personnel and visitor/contractors if an uncontrolled ammonia leak occurs, large or small. Plant employee/operators will not respond directly to an ammonia leak and attempt to mitigate a catastrophic release. Instead they will support and communicate with emergency responders, local response agencies, and provide outside agency notification in the event of an uncontrolled ammonia release. The emergency action plan provides for the evacuation of Blissfield facility personnel and visitors. The Airgas Blissfield facility has provided their emergency action plan to and coordinates the plan annually with a local Blissfield Fire Station and Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). Should an emergency involving the release of ammonia occur that will have off-site consequences, Airgas will contact the Fire Department and local support authorities, who will coordinate appropriate action for the affected community.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Safety is an inherent part of the culture at Airgas and enhancements in safety and operations are actively discussed and supported. The Blissfield CO2 production facility continues to review its processes for possibilities of improvement to the covered ammonia process, operational methods, and new technology to lower risk.  Planned improvements over the next five years include:

1. Fixed gas detection

2. Compressor rebuild

3. Man down system for lone worker
